articles.headline: Trump’s Rise Inspires a Rush to Publish (and Exhume) Books About Him
articles.snippet: Every election brings a wave of political books, but this year is already exceptional in terms of how many have Donald Trump as the central character.
articles.abstract: Every election brings a wave of political books, but this year is already exceptional in terms of how many have Donald Trump as the central character.
articles.lead_paragraph: On his bedroom wall, the New Yorker writer Mark Singer has a framed, handwritten note from Donald J. Trump. “Mark, you are a total loser! And your book (and writings) sucks!” the note says.

articles.headline: New Payday Options for Making Ends Meet
articles.snippet: Employers and start-ups are testing ways to give employees faster access to their wages.
articles.abstract: Employers and start-ups are testing ways to give employees faster access to their wages.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, most American companies have paid their workers once every week or two, minimizing the administrative costs of frequent paydays and maximizing the interest the companies earn by keeping the money in the bank.

articles.headline: Turkish Leader Erdogan Making New Enemies and Frustrating Old Friends
articles.snippet: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan long professed a foreign policy of “zero problems with neighbors” but now seems mired in disputes with just about everybody.
articles.abstract: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan long professed a foreign policy of “zero problems with neighbors” but now seems mired in disputes with just about everybody.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Turkey’s president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, strode onto a stage a month ago looking down upon a sea of a million fans waving red Turkish flags. They were celebrating the 15th-century conquest of Istanbul by the Ottoman sultan Mehmed II, the golden moment of Turkey’s Muslim ancestors triumphing over the Christian West.

articles.headline: Tesla and Google Take Different Roads to Self-Driving Car
articles.snippet: Two self-driving car pioneers have distinct views of the role of the person behind the wheel.
articles.abstract: Two self-driving car pioneers have distinct views of the role of the person behind the wheel.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In Silicon Valley, where companies big and small are at work on self-driving cars, there have been a variety of approaches, and even some false starts.

articles.headline: California Drug Price Plan Is Criticized by Patient Advocates
articles.snippet: A California initiative meant to lower skyrocketing prescription drug prices faces opposition from not only drug makers but also some patient advocacy groups.
articles.abstract: A California initiative meant to lower skyrocketing prescription drug prices faces opposition from not only drug makers but also some patient advocacy groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A state ballot initiative meant to lower prescription drug prices for California faces an expected opponent: the pharmaceutical industry, which has spent almost $70 million to defeat it.

articles.headline: One Robber’s 3 Life Sentences: ’90s Legacy Fills Prisons Today
articles.snippet: The era’s zero tolerance of drug users helped lead to a life term for Lenny Singleton, one of tens of thousands of such inmates across the country.
articles.abstract: The era’s zero tolerance of drug users helped lead to a life term for Lenny Singleton, one of tens of thousands of such inmates across the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: BURKEVILLE, Va. — Lenny Singleton is the first to admit that he deserved an extended stay behind bars. To fuel his crack habit back in 1995, he walked into 13 stores over eight days and either distracted a clerk or pretended to have a concealed gun before stealing from the cash register. One time, he was armed with a knife with a six-inch blade that he had brought from his kitchen.

articles.headline: Quiet Fixer in Donald Trump’s Campaign: His Son-in-Law, Jared Kushner
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump has long preferred the advice of family over political operatives, and Mr. Kushner is seen as a de facto campaign manager.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump has long preferred the advice of family over political operatives, and Mr. Kushner is seen as a de facto campaign manager.
articles.lead_paragraph: International diplomacy is a world of careful rituals, hierarchy and credentials. But when the Israeli ambassador to the United States, Ron Dermer, wanted to communicate with Donald J. Trump, he ended up on two occasions in the Manhattan office of a young man with no government experience, no political background and no official title in the Trump campaign: Jared Kushner.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and Jonathan Mahler

articles.headline: A Reading List of Tell-Alls, Strategic Plans and Cautionary Tales in Finance
articles.snippet: Books to get you caught up on influential deal makers, activist shareholders, the failings of the modern economy and the habits of highly successful people.
articles.abstract: Books to get you caught up on influential deal makers, activist shareholders, the failings of the modern economy and the habits of highly successful people.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the summer upon us and the so-called Brexit vote behind us, perhaps you might have some time to read one of the terrific books published recently that touch on big themes in business, finance and technology. I’ve been plowing through stacks of them to make your life simpler. Here are some of my favorites.

articles.headline: Young Performers Look to Apps for Stardom
articles.snippet: YouNow, a live-streaming app that allows users to perform and interact with fans, has helped singers like Hailey Knox break into the industry.
articles.abstract: YouNow, a live-streaming app that allows users to perform and interact with fans, has helped singers like Hailey Knox break into the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — At VidCon, a sprawling conference here for the young stars of online video, success has a particular sound: a sudden, earsplitting shriek, signaling that a legion of tween-age fans have spotted one of their idols and are making a frantic selfie run.

articles.headline: Financial Strain Grows From ‘Brexit’ Vote
articles.snippet: As bond yields and the pound decline, three major real estate funds have suspended payouts, a rare move that reflects mounting industry concerns.
articles.abstract: As bond yields and the pound decline, three major real estate funds have suspended payouts, a rare move that reflects mounting industry concerns.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The financial strains from Britain’s vote to leave the European Union are starting to show, as worries ripple through the country’s real estate market.

articles.headline: F.B.I. Director James Comey Recommends No Charges for Hillary Clinton on Email
articles.snippet: The director said that “no reasonable prosecutor” would bring a case but called Mrs. Clinton and her staff “extremely careless” in their use of email.
articles.abstract: The director said that “no reasonable prosecutor” would bring a case but called Mrs. Clinton and her staff “extremely careless” in their use of email.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, on Tuesday recommended no criminal charges against Hillary Clinton for her handling of classified information while she was secretary of state, lifting an enormous legal cloud from her presidential campaign less than two hours before she boarded Air Force One for her first joint campaign appearance with President Obama.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Eric Lichtblau

articles.headline: Welsh Reject E.U., but Its Money Will Be Missed
articles.snippet: One of the looming questions in the aftermath of the “Brexit” vote is what happens to European Union aid flowing into places like Wales.
articles.abstract: One of the looming questions in the aftermath of the “Brexit” vote is what happens to European Union aid flowing into places like Wales.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEWPORT, Wales — David Adams co-owns a painting business here. His leanings in the recent referendum to leave the European Union would seem obvious.
